articles.title: 2 weeks of record heat: B.C. hits multiple high temperature marks for 14th straight day
articles.author: Ian Holliday
articles.summary: Lytton, Lillooet, Summerland, Smithers and Tatlayoko Lake saw their hottest Sept. 4 on record Thursday, continuing a streak of daily records that began two weeks ago on Aug. 22. The forecast for the coming week shows cooler temperatures and possible showers in Metro Vancouver.

articles.title: Deforestation linked to half a million deaths in past 20 years
articles.author: Jonathan Watts
articles.summary: Deforestation has killed more than half a million people in the tropics over the past two decades. Land clearance is raising the temperature in the rainforests of the Amazon, Congo and southeast Asia because it reduces shade, a study has found. The Guardian and Climate Desk collaborated on this article.

articles.title: Top energy official who deals with climate change says it isn't real
articles.author: Walter Einenkel
articles.summary: Chris Wright is the Energy Secretary in the Trump administration. In an interview with the Council on Foreign Affairs, he pushed the blatant lie that climate change isn't a big issue. Extreme weather damage as a percent of the economy globally and in the U.S. is on decline.

articles.title: Frost advisory issued for parts of southern and central Sask.
articles.author: Caitlin Brezinski
articles.summary: A frost advisory has been issued for southern and central parts of Saskatchewan, including Regina and Saskatoon, on Friday. A patchy frost is expected to develop across parts of the province Friday night and into Saturday morning. People are advised to cover up plants in frost-prone areas and take preventative measures to protect frost-sensitive plants.

articles.title: Watch Earth's Seasons Change the Face of the Planet in a New Animated Map
articles.author: Drew Terasaki Hart
articles.summary: In a new study in Nature, Terasaki Hart and his colleagues present an intimate portrait of the seasonal cycles of Earth's land-based ecosystems. They show there are 'hotspots' of seasonal asynchrony around the world, where the timing of seasonal cycles can be out of sync between nearby locations. Mediterranean climates and their neighboring drylands are hotspots of out-of-sync seasonal activity. They overlap with Earth's biodiversity hotspots.

articles.title: Last year was region's hottest on record
articles.author: The BVI Beacon
articles.summary: In 2024, the region's average annual temperature was 26.81 degrees Celsius, 0.84 degree above the 1991-2020 average. The December-to-February and March- to-May periods also set seasonal records. Last year was the eighth wettest year since 1950, with average rainfall at 114 percent of normal levels.

articles.title: Bahrain News: Arab achievers shine as book of records marks milestone
articles.author: Julia Cassano
articles.summary: Guinness World Records (GWR) has highlighted the record-breaking achievements of the Arab world, including Bahrain, as it celebrates 70 years of chronicling the extraordinary across the globe. GWR has more than 65,000 awesome records in its database, including 1,600 from the Arab region.

articles.title: Broken Fields
articles.author: Sajid Salamat
articles.summary: Most of Punjab and Sindh's farmlands are under water due to recent floods. 60% of the rice crop, 35% of cotton and 30% of sugarcane are already lost in central and southern Punjab. More than 1.8 million people across the Chenab, Ravi, and Sutlej river basins are already suffering. The losses already run into billions of rupees. Pakistan's food security is at grave risk. The government must declare an agricultural emergency today. Interest-free loans of up to Rs2 million for small and medium farmers are an investment in the nation's future.

articles.title: $221 million disaster relief grant signed to help Helene impacted farmers
articles.author: WITN Web Team
articles.summary: $221 million grant was signed by Agriculture Commissioner Steve Troxler and USDA Deputy Secretary Stephen Valden to help farmers with production losses from Hurricane Helene. 39 counties that received a Presidential Disaster Declaration will acquire the funds. Some farmers may have to sign with USDA Risk Management coverage for two crop years for market loss, future economic loss, plasticulture, and aquaculture claims.

articles.title: Live in a hurricane-prone area? Here's how to prepare your home for flooding
articles.author: Wusf
articles.summary: This year's hurricane season is already generating a lot of anxiety. Steve Papola's home in Hudson, Florida, was destroyed by Hurricane Helene last year. He had 4 feet of storm surge push onto his house. Flooding from hurricanes is becoming more intense due to human-caused climate change. The number of people living in flood-prone areas has increased.

articles.title: Mounting flood devastation
articles.author: editorial
articles.summary: Floods in Punjab have destroyed 60% of the rice crop, 35% of cotton and 30% of sugarcane in central and southern Punjab. More than 1.8 million people have been affected. The Pakistan Business Forum has urged the government to declare an agricultural emergency.

articles.title: Tech Update: What Frontier's Planetary pledge means for the planet's future
articles.author: Rebecca Gao
articles.summary: To avoid climate catastrophe, we need to do more than reduce emissions, says the UNFCCC's chief scientist, Michael Schumacher. The effects of global warming are getting more extreme and harder to ignore.       .   i

articles.title: 50-plus archaeological sites on Easter Island could become submerged
articles.author: Osvaldo Silva
articles.summary: Rising sea levels could flood more than 50 archaeological sites on Easter Island, or Rapa Nui, by 2080, according to a new study from the University of Hawaii. The research highlights the impact of climate change on the island's cultural and tourism heritage. Ahu Tongariki, the largest group of moai statues on the Easter Island is at risk of flooding in less than 60 years.

articles.title: Climate Experts Correct Joe Rogan's Misinterpretation of Temperature Trends, Emphasizing Earth's Ongoing Warming Crisis
articles.author: Sophie Lin
articles.summary: Joe Rogan presented data suggesting a cooling trend on the Joe Rogan Experience podcast. Climate scientists have refuted these claims. The core issue lies in selective data presentation and a misunderstanding of long-term climate patterns. The scientific consensus is that human activities are the dominant driver of current climate change.

articles.title: Physics-based indicator predicts tipping point for collapse of Atlantic current system in next 50 years
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) is an enormous loop of ocean current in the Atlantic Ocean that carries warmer waters. It is a loop in which warmer waters are carried by Atlantic Ocean currents. It's responsible for the warming of the ocean.

articles.title: What climate change means for the Mediterranean Sea
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Temperatures in the Mediterranean are currently rising to record levels. Holidaymakers in Greece, Italy and Greece are taking advantage of the warm weather.    in Greece and Italy are taking a break from the heat.  In Greece, people are going for holidays.

articles.title: Where is the largest natural hot spring on Earth found?
articles.author: TOI Lifestyle Desk
articles.summary: Frying Pan Lake is the largest natural hot spring in the world. It is located in the Waimangu Volcanic Rift Valley in New Zealand's North Island. It got its name from its steaming, bubbling surface that resembles a sizzling skillet. The lake is fed by geothermal vents deep within the Earth's crust, where magma heats groundwater to create scalding, acidic waters.

articles.title: Cochinita — I still have dreams about this Mexican delicacy
articles.author: Boing Boing
articles.summary: I lived in San Miguel de Cozumel, Mexico, for long enough that I got used to the heat. There are a lot of things I don't like about living in Mexico, but there are also things I do like.

articles.title: Has the world broken heat records in recent years?
articles.author: Reginald David
articles.summary: According to the World Meteorological Organization and NOAA, every year from 2015 to 2024 ranked among the 10 warmest years on record. WMO confirmed in January that 2024 was the hottest year ever recorded, beating the record set just one year prior. Global temperatures in 2024 were about 2.3 degrees Fahrenheit higher than the 20th-century average. For 14 straight months, through July 2024, the world set new monthly heat records.

articles.title: Atlantic cyclone probability increases to 90 percent
articles.author: Yucatan Times
articles.summary: Conagua is monitoring a low-pressure zone in the Atlantic Ocean. It is located southwest of the Cape Verde Islands, 5,635 kilometers from Quintana Roo. The weather agency adds that it is moving slowly westward at a speed of between 8 and 16 km/h (5 to 10 mph). Forecasts indicate it is expected to strengthen into a tropical depression this weekend.

articles.title: Earth's seasons have gone wackadoodle
articles.author: Devika Rao
articles.summary: Earth contains hotspots that are seasonally "asynchronous" with surrounding areas. This irregularity can have surprising ecological, evolutionary and even economic consequences. Human activity is changing the seasons and causing a rise in syncopated seasons, which can be dangerous for humans and ecosystems.

articles.title: Chennai among coastal cities most at risk from rising sea level, finds study
articles.author: The Hindu Bureau
articles.summary: Chennai and other cities along India's eastern coast face heightened risks from sea-level rise, according to a new study by scientists from Anna University and the Tamil Nadu Green Climate Company. The study shows that the Bay of Bengal is experiencing accelerated sea level rise compared to the Arabian Sea. The 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami exposed the fragility of the state's shores.

articles.title: New Study Reveals Rapid Insect Decline in Pristine Ecosystems
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: There is a 72.4% decline in flying insect abundance in subalpine meadow ecosystem in Colorado due to climate change. The research was conducted by researchers at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Mountainous regions, often considered refuges for endemic species, may be more vulnerable than previously understood. The study's results illuminate gaps in current biodiversity monitoring frameworks.

articles.title: Unveiling North America's Influence on Asia's Monsoons: New
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: Summer heating over North America triggers atmospheric processes that significantly enhance rainfall across East and South Asia. This discovery underscores the intricate teleconnections embedded within Earth's climate system and highlights the far-reaching impacts of regional land surface changes. The insights carry profound implications in the context of anthropogenic climate change.

articles.title: Pakistan under water
articles.author: Abdul Basit Alvi
articles.summary: Pakistan is one of the most climate-vulnerable countries. Climate change is a threat to Pakistan's environment, its economy, and the livelihood of millions. Pakistan must adopt an urgent, comprehensive, and multi-pronged approach to tackle climate change. The first step is to integrate climate resilience into its national planning and governance framework. Strengthening water infrastructure is essential.

articles.title: From ski trails to hiking paths, extreme heat is reshaping recreation, and our attitudes
articles.author: Terry L. Jones
articles.summary: Extreme heat is reshaping recreation and our attitudes. Rising temps fuel greater concern about climate change than wildfires or hurricanes, according to researchers.    .      - Floodlightnews.org is part of the BLOX Digital Content Exchange.

articles.title: Afghanistan Quakes Halt Relief Efforts as Aftershocks and Rain Threaten Worsening Crisis
articles.author: Fidel Rahmati
articles.summary: Aftershocks and looming heavy rains in Afghanistan's eastern provinces of Nangarhar and Kunar have heightened humanitarian concerns. The World Food Programme warned that urgent needs in the quake-hit areas will rise sharply. Jan Egeland, Secretary General of the Norwegian Refugee Council, urged donor countries to renew their support for Afghanistan.

articles.title: HSRC Webinar Sets Stage for Africa's Climate Futures Conference in Namibia
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The Human Sciences Research Council is hosting a webinar ahead of the 3rd Climate Change and Futures in Africa Conference. The virtual event is scheduled between 11am and 1pm. It is being held in collaboration with the University of Venda (South Africa), Midlands State University (Zimbabwe), and the National Youth Climate Action Network of Namibia. The conference will take place in Windhoek, Namibia, from 29 October to 1 November 2025.

articles.title: ‘Hoax!' A Physicist's Case Against The CO2-Driven Climate Narrative
articles.author: Petter Tuvnes
articles.summary: Darwin Throne's new book, Hoax! Why Burning Fossil Fuels Doesn't Cause Climate Change, presents a new thermodynamic climate paradigm that aligns with reality. Nobel laureate John Clauser calls the greenhouse theory 'pseudoscience'. The UN's IPCC's work is based on the greenhouse effect, where heat radiation from greenhouse gases drive global warming.

articles.title: Warmest winter for some
articles.author: John Lewis
articles.summary: Puysegur Point in Southland and South West Cape on Stewart Island had their warmest winter on record this year. Milford Sound set a record mean maximum air temperature for winter with 11.4°C - its highest since records began in 1934. The highest winter temperature in New Zealand was on June 5, when the mercury reached 23.2°C at Whakatu, and the lowest was -12.9°C on Mt Cook airport on June 8.

articles.title: Weather warning: Expect uneven, less rainfall
articles.author: Ndubi Moturi
articles.summary: Most parts of Kenya will experience below average rainfall between now and December 2025. Longer dry spells will continue to affect counties, although some will experience the occasional storm. Turkana and Western Samburu are expected to record near-to-slightly-below-average rainfall. The highlands east of the Rift Valley, Nairobi, Nyeri, Kirinyaga, Murang'a, Kiambu, Meru, Nyandarua, Embu, and Tharaka-Nithi are also expected to receive below-average rain.

articles.title: Extreme weather already cost Luxembourg over €1bn
articles.author: Pierre Pailler
articles.summary: Climatic events like heavy rain, storms and floods caused €1.262 billion in economic losses in Luxembourg between 1980 and 2023. Luxembourg comes fourth in the EU in terms of economic losses per km², behind Germany, Belgium, Belgium and Slovenia. Most of the more than €790 billion in European economic losses recorded in Europe over the period came from bigger EU countries.

articles.title: Spain's average August temperature ties 2024 record high
articles.author: Sharjah 24
articles.summary: The country experienced a record-breaking heatwave last month. The Carlos III Health Institute estimates that the heatwave caused over 1,100 deaths, primarily among people over 65. Over 380,000 hectares (nearly 1,500 square miles) of land have burned this year due to wildfires.

articles.title: Climate change turns Pakistan's summer oases into deadly flood zones
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: Climate change turns Pakistan's summer oases into deadly flood zones, as reported by The Washington Post. The area is one of the world's most flood-prone areas. The country's summers are becoming more dangerous because of the climate change.    for the Washington Post

articles.title: These are the coldest countries in the world
articles.summary: The coldest countries are generally found in the polar regions and in high latitudes. The countries showcase diverse climates within their borders, ranging from subarctic to Arctic conditions, with long, frigid winters and brief summers. Click on to see which nations made the list.

articles.title: New Study: Higher CO2 Levels Do Not Precede Or Control Temperature Increases
articles.author: Kenneth Richard
articles.summary: A correlation analysis of temperature and CO2 data from the past 2,000 years shows that CO2 changes lag temperature changes by 150 years from 1 to 1850 CE (Common Era). This is consistent with the paleo CO2 and temperature proxy record spanning the last 20,000 to 400 million years, 66 million years and 420 million years.

articles.title: Looking back on autumn: season of mists and mellow fruitfulness
articles.author: Sarah Millington
articles.summary: Autumn is one of the four temperate seasons on Earth. Outside the tropics, it marks the transition from summer to winter in September (Northern Hemisphere) or March (Southern Hemisphere). Day length decreases and night length increases as the season progresses. Autumn is the season when the duration of daylight becomes noticeably shorter and the temperature cools.

articles.title: Heavy rain in Odisha leaves rivers in spate, flood threat looms
articles.author: Rajendra Prasad Mohapatra
articles.summary: Continuous heavy rainfall has triggered a rise in water levels of the Jalaka and Budhabalanga rivers in Balasore district on Friday. Water has started inundating farmlands and several villages in the Balasores Sadar area, with floodwaters flowing over roads near Gujuri Bazar Square. If flooding occurs, at least 10 panchayats under the Basta block, including Mathani, Baharda, and Kudia, are likely to be severely affected. Thousands of hectares of farmland, where paddy was recently transplanted, are at risk of submergence. Yellow warning has been issued for 20 districts.

articles.title: #HaveItBothWays: The disappearing Pacific coral atolls
articles.author: John Robson
articles.summary: There is a growing concern about sea level rise and the sinking of Pacific islands like Tuvalu and Vanuatu. A 2006 study concludes that the sea level is rising in the tropical Pacific and that this is a cause for concern for climate change alarmists.

articles.title: US military backs albatross-inspired drone aiming for longer flight on less power
articles.author: Interesting Engineering
articles.summary: Birds can soar through the sky without flapping their wings. A team of researchers is exploring the science of autonomous soaring and developing technology that could dramatically reduce the amount of energy UASs require. They are excited about the opportunity to explore the science and develop technology.

articles.title: PISLM mission to Petite Martinique to assess land degradation
articles.author: Now Grenada
articles.summary: A team from the Partnership Initiative for Sustainable Land Management (PISLM) visited Petite Martinique on 3 September 2025 as part of an urgent mission to assess the extent of land degradation worsened by the recent passage of Hurricane Beryl. PISLM has completed a baseline analysis, which will be submitted to the Ministry of Carriacou and Petite Martine. The analysis will provide the basis for planning and initiating targeted on-the-ground interventions aimed at restoring the degraded lands.

articles.title: Warming temperatures can impact animals' reproduction survival Studies
articles.summary: Two studies have found that extreme temperatures can change how a species reproduces. Biodiversity is disappearing at an alarming rate due to human activity and climate change. One study looked at the Guibe's ground gecko and the other at the central bearded dragon.

articles.title: Sea Levels Not Surging Despite Years Of Climate Activists And Corporate Media Freaking Out, Study Finds
articles.author: Audrey Streb
articles.summary: A recent study compiled sea level rise data shows oceans are not surging as much as the scientific world previously projected. Energy policy experts told the Daily Caller News Foundation that the study challenges mainstream climate change orthodoxy. Heartland Institute director Sterling Burnett said that in the few places where sea levels are rising faster than average, the cause is probably local factors.

articles.title: Your letters to the editor: September 5
articles.summary: Brandon Abdinor's claim that we are heating the planet by emitting greenhouse gases into the atmosphere from burning fossil fuels is debunked by science. The UN Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) has acknowledged in its fifth assessment report that 'economic damage from global warming is negligible'

articles.title: 'An antacid for soil'? Here's a fresh crop of climate news.
articles.author: Janet Wilson
articles.summary: According to a new poll, 86% of Americans think FEMA's services after a natural disaster are necessary or somewhat necessary. Native youths aged 13 to 20 from seven tribes made the journey from tributary headwaters down the once again free flowing Klamath River in northern California to a joyful celebration at its mouth. The final full moon of summer 2025 – known as the corn moon – will reach peak illumination on Sunday, September 7.

articles.title: AUSTRALIA RIVERFIRE PREVIEW
articles.author: DE MR CJ
articles.summary: Riverfire festival media preview in Brisbane. EA-18G Growler flies over Brisbane City during a media preview of Riverfire in Brisbane, Australia, on 5 September 2025. AUSTRALIA AND NEW ZEALAND ARE OUT of the festival, which is in Australia and New Zealand.

articles.title: Wildfires producing 'witches' brew' of air pollution: UN
articles.author: Robin Millard
articles.summary: Wildfires are releasing a 'witches' brew' of pollutants that can wreck air quality a continent away from the blaze, the UN's weather and climate agency said Friday. The biggest PM 2.5 surge was in the Amazon basin, but it was also in Canada, Siberia and central Africa. The World Meteorological Organization said the quality of the air people breathe is interlinked with climate change and needs to be tackled together.

articles.title: UN Report Warns Wildfires Driving Global Air Pollution Surge
articles.author: Israa Farhan
articles.summary: Wildfires worsened global air quality in 2024, according to a report by the World Meteorological Organization. Canada, Siberia and central Africa recorded above-average PM2.5 levels in 2024. The Amazon basin suffered the sharpest surge. The report also noted some positive developments, including sustained reductions in particle pollution in Eastern China.

articles.title: Oceans may face dual threats from humans in the next 25 years
articles.summary: A new study published in Science warns that the human impact on the oceans could double by 2050 if current trends continue. Rising global temperatures are heating oceans at an accelerating pace, while unregulated fishing and maritime trade further intensify the strain. Many nations reliant on the ocean for food and employment will be the hardest hit.

articles.title: World's largest iceberg A23A breaks apart in Antarctic death spiral, unlikely to survive past November
articles.author: Trending Desk
articles.summary: The world's largest and longest-lasting iceberg, known as A23A, is breaking apart and shrinking steadily. It is unlikely to survive beyond November. The melting of floating ice shelves accelerates the flow of land-based glaciers into the ocean, which contributes to rising seas over time.

articles.title: These cities may disappear by 2030
articles.summary: Climate Central has created a map showing which parts of the world could find themselves threatened by rising sea levels due to global warming. The map shows which cities could be below tide level as early as 2030. If governments don't take serious action to address the climate crisis, these studies can help us prepare for the potential consequences.

articles.title: UK suffers worst ever year for wildfires with total set to eclipse 1,000
articles.summary: There have been 996 wildfires in England and Wales so far in 2025, exceeding the previous high of 994 incidents recorded in 2022. The recent wildfires have kept firefighter teams occupied for several days, imposing significant physical and emotional strain on them. There has been a 25% decline in firefighter numbers since 2008. Incident volumes rose 20% since 2014.

articles.title: Spain's average August temperature matched 2024 record
articles.summary: The average temperature in August hit 25 degrees Celsius, matching the national record set in 2024. Aemet registered 77 heatwaves in Spain since 1975, with six going 4 degrees Celsius or more above the average. August's heatwave was the most intense on record, with average temperatures 4.6 degrees Celsius above previous events.

articles.title: World weather agency warns of vicious cycle in air and climate
articles.author: CGTN
articles.summary: Fossil fuel burning and human activities contribute to climate change, which in turn aggravates climate change. The World Meteorological Organization (WMO) issues an annual report for the International Day of Clean Air for Blue Skies to be marked on September 7. The report details the dangerous feedback loop between climate change and air pollution, driven significantly by tiny airborne particles known as aerosols.

articles.title: Letters to the Editor: We can't let ‘anti-science' push back our efforts to rein in climate change
articles.summary: To the editor, Maggie Wineburgh-Freed, John Beckman, Gregg Ferry and Tom Hazelleaf, we are playing Russian roulette with our policy regarding climate change. They argue that we should stop subsidizing fossil fuels with our lives and dollars.

articles.title: Desertification and wildfires in Spain. The impact of climate change on bank lending (Banco de España)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: Desertification and the greater severity and frequency of wildfires pose a major climate change threat in Spain. The impact of climate change on bank lending is a concern for Laura Álvarez, Carmen Broto, Olivier Hubert, Sergio Mayordomo and others.

articles.title: Hurricane Kiko approaches Hawaii as dangerous Category 4 storm
articles.author: Web Desk
articles.summary: Hurricane Kiko is a Category 4 storm with sustained winds reaching 140 mph. It's tracking toward the Hawaiian Islands with potential impact in early to mid-September 2025. The storm's exact path remains uncertain. The potential effects include destructive winds, flooding rainfall, coastal hazards, power outage, property damage, flash flooding and life-threatening rip currents.

articles.title: Human Impact on Marine Life Set to Double by 2050, Scientists Warn
articles.author: Ishwi Singh
articles.summary: A new study predicts human impact on the ocean could double by 2050. Overfishing, ocean warming, rising sea levels, pollution, and acidification are affecting marine environments. Coastal areas will be the most affected. People living near the coast depend heavily on the oceans for food, income, and resources.

articles.title: Africa Climate Communication Summit to shape the continent's narrative ahead of COP30
articles.summary: Stories for Change Foundation is convening the first Africa Climate Communication Summit (virtual edition) on September 21-22, 2025. It is a call to reclaim Africa's climate story, to strengthen indigenous knowledge, and to put communities at the heart of the conversation as the world prepares for COP30 in Brazil.

articles.title: A Climate Giant Long Thought Dormant May Be Waking Up, Scientists Warn
articles.author: Katy Stublen
articles.summary: For decades, scientists treated certain planetary systems as stable. New measurements suggest the sleeping giants of the climate are stirring again. The data doesn't whisper, but pulses with urgency. The world is edging closer to thresholds once considered unimaginable, as the data suggests.

articles.title: Extreme weather threatens $1.1 trillion in Texas property. Few are prepared.
articles.author: Chris Tomlinson
articles.summary: $1.1 trillion in Texas real estate is at risk from climate change-related disasters, according to a new Realtor.com report. One in four homes in Texas faces severe or extreme risks from flooding, hurricanes or wildfires. Every region of the state has faced extreme weather events, from Hurricane Harvey in 2017 and Winter Storm Uri in 2021 to the deadly Kerr County floods in July. President Donald Trump's administration has taken down government data about climate change and the threat it poses to the United States.

articles.title: There Is No Cataclysmic Sea Level Rise
articles.author: Nate Jackson
articles.summary: There is no evidence that global sea levels are rising due to climate change. Dutch researchers compared projections from the UN's Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change against real-world measurements. They found that the majority of the local causes of rapid sea level rise (or drop) appear to be geologic. The median increase was 1.5 millimeters per year, which is significantly lower than the 3 to 4 mm/year often reported by climate scientists and the media.

articles.title: Climate-driven wildfires spike air pollution: WMO
articles.author: --Ppa-Color-Scheme
articles.summary: Air pollution caused by wildfires contributed to air pollution last year, according to a report by the World Meteorological Organisation (WMO). The WHO says ambient air pollution causes 4.5 million premature deaths a year. Wildfires have become more frequent and extensive around the globe due to climate change.

articles.title: Climate change turns Pakistan's summer oases into deadly flood zones
articles.author: The Washington Post
articles.summary: Floods inundate mountain retreats where Pakistanis go to escape the summer heat this year. Climate change is to blame for the problem.       in Pakistan's mountains are inundated this year by floods, another product of climate change.

articles.title: UN links rising wildfires to global pollution surge
articles.author: Maleeha Zahid
articles.summary: The World Meteorological Organization (WMO) has reported that wildfires, made more frequent by climate change, significantly increased air pollution in 2024. WMO highlighted pollution hotspots in regions affected by intense fires, including the Amazon, Canada, Siberia, and central Africa, where smoke and particulates worsened air quality for millions of people.

articles.title: Send in your questions for the Guardian's climate assembly panel
articles.author: Guardian community team
articles.summary: On Tuesday 16 September, a Guardian panel of experts will be looking to answer questions about the forces driving the pushback against a greener world. The live event in London will start with a special welcome address from the Guardian's editor-in-chief Katharine Viner. They will be joined by the Guardian columnist George Monbiot, Mikaela Loach, Emma Pinchbeck and Feargal Sharkey. This panel discussion will also be livestreamed globally.

articles.title: Gathering of geese
articles.author: I Work In The Mediums
articles.summary: In recent years the Canada goose population has increased dramatically in Minnesota and the Midwest. State wildlife agencies have increased bag limits and season lengths to keep the population in check. Many Canada geese stay in Minnesota throughout the winter, although some migrate south to any number of states.

articles.title: From wildfires to murky seas: Why Europe needs 'Areas Under Restoration'
articles.author: Jordi Oliva Farriol
articles.summary: This August, Spain recorded its hottest temperatures in more than 70 years. Across the country, wildfires devastated rural communities, forests, and farmland. As we speak, wildfires continue to devastate rural communities and forests, as well as farmland, as we speak. As a result, many people are homeless.

articles.title: Wildfires creating ‘witches' brew' of air pollution: UN
articles.summary: Wildfires are releasing dangerous mix of pollutants that can travel across continents and severely degrade air quality, according to the World Meteorological Organization. Wildfires in 2024 led to above-average PM 2.5 levels in Canada, Siberia, and central Africa, with the Amazon basin recording the largest surge. Air pollution currently contributes to more than 4.5 million premature deaths globally each year.

articles.title: Greens' ‘visceral reaction' to Australian flag in Senate labelled hypocrisy
articles.summary: Liberal Senator Alex Antic discusses how the Australian Greens have such a 'visceral reaction' to the Australian flag in the Senate. Mr Antic believes the rules in the senate are odd to the strict letter of the law, but it's arguable that that's right.

articles.title: Fires in Spain and Portugal fueled by climate change
articles.author: Deutsche Welle
articles.summary: Wildfires caused devastation in Spain and Portugal this summer. Scientists say rising global temperatures caused by burning fossil fuels has made the deadly fires 40 times more likely to occur. The cause of global warming is the burning of fossil fuels, which is linked to climate change.

articles.title: When Floods Favour The Powerful
articles.author: Dr. Noreen Saher
articles.summary: Floods in Pakistan are a recurring crisis that expose the fragile nexus between society, state, and ecology. In rural areas, influential landowners and industrialists use political connections to divert floodwaters away from their estates to protect their assets. The recent case of the Ramzan Sugar Mill illustrates this starkly: floodwaters were redirected towards poor villages to protect elite-owned assets. For the poor, the consequences are immediate and long-term.

articles.title: Big Business Still Trying To Hold Back Climate Action
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The Business Council of Australia's climate change target for 2035 lacks credibility, according to ACF. ACF's Gavan McFadzean believes Australia should set a 2035 target of no less than 80% for climate change action. ACf also criticises the Frontier Economics-style modelling used by BCA.

articles.title: These countries are the hottest in the world
articles.summary: There are 30 hottest countries in the world, according to the average yearly temperature and their highest ever recorded temperature. Click on the gallery to see which countries made it to the top 30 and their hottest ever recorded temperatures.    ...   .

articles.title: WNC restaurants, farmers call for support to save industries following Helene
articles.author: Tiana Kennell
articles.summary: Tropical Storm Helene hit Western North Carolina nearly one year ago. James Beard Foundation's Climate Solutions for Restaurant Survival Campaign held a roundtable discussion in downtown Asheville on Sept. 4. It focused on the urgent need for disaster relief, investments in climate resilience, disaster relief and insurance, tariffs and food equity.

articles.title: Greenpeace Blasts BCA for Dangerous Report
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Greenpeace is critical of the Business Council of Australia's latest report and modelling as dangerous, delusional and unaligned with the latest science. BCA's report comes as Australia looks to submit its 2035 climate target under the Paris Agreement in the coming weeks. Greenpeace points to the questionable credibility of the consulting firm used to produce the modelling, McKinsey, which has an extensive history working with the fossil fuel industry.

articles.title: The Climate Change Playbook No Longer Works. What Can Activists Do? – The New York Times
articles.author: News Feed Editor
